div.p: these grand theories effectively push cities like Nairobi, Duoala and elsewhere 'off the map' of structural relevance. Ordinary cities offers a new and exciting approach to urban processes. Whilst the grand claim of the book that all cities are ordinary provides a useful starting point for rethinking urban studies, the argument does not as yet provide us with sufficient conceptual clarity that can enable us to differentiate and make distinctions between cities. The anti-hierarchical stance helps us to understand the problems with the modernist and developmentalist bias of conventional urban studies. Yet we also need tools to distinguish between cities if we are to escape the dangers of cultural relativism. Still, Robinson's work provides an important point of departure for developing a postcolonial urban studies. Ordinary cities is a useful book for its telling critiques of modernity and developmentalism. It starts the process of providing an alternative approach that breaks with Western-dominated thinking in urban studies. Department of Sociology AZAT ZANA GU¨ NDOG AN State University of New York MARTIN J. MURRAY Binghamton Concubines and power: five hundred years in a northern Nigerian palace. By Heidi J. Nast. Minneapolis: University of Minneapolis Press. 2005. xxx '/245pp. ISBN 0 8166 4154 4. This excellent study, the outcome of 15 years of field research, concerns the place of concubines in the commercial kingdom of Kano in what is now northern Nigeria. From the sixteenth century, the city-state of Kano was the principal focus of inland West African trade, and Heidi Nast shows here how its political and cultural life depended on the institution of concubinage, particularly as it was developed under Islam, where it was linked to the principles of female seclusion and to the patriarchal centralization of the state. She demonstrates, principally through a socio-spatial extrapolation of the royal palace complex, how Islam reoriented the landscape according to principles of interiority and integrity. The seclusion of women established the symbolic equivalences between gendered bodies and the state's imaginary; but concubine women also played a key economic role in the politico-economic integration of the state, as collectors and administrators of the tax in grain. Concubines were thus key economic and political actors, and Nast clearly identifies the centrality of fertility and reproduction to the life of the kingdom Á and not just the bounty of the land, but also the bearing of children, the state's principal currency. In Kano, concubines were usually prisoners of war, but their children were born free and amongst their number were possible future kings: the management of reproduction thus lay at the core of political life. All this came to an end, predictably enough, with the regional dominance of the British at the beginning of the twentieth century. Though the institutions were on the wane long before this, the British conceived concubinage simply as a form of 164 cultural geographies 14(1) slavery, desexualizing it as it was stripped of its political and economic importance, and turning it into the private, domestic affair that it never was. This abjection of the 'harem' dissolved the concubine spaces and turned their inhabitants out into a hostile colonial world. In our own day, with grain delivered by trucks, there is little reminder of this long-lost, complex and multi-layered institution; but Heidi Nast's book recovers and reconstitutes this world. It is an imaginative and innovative contribution to cultural geography. Department of Geography PHILIP HOWELL University of Cambridge Suffering for territory: race, place, and power in Zimbabwe. By Donald S. Moore. Durham, NC: Duke University Press. 2005. 399 pp. $84.95 cloth; $23.95 paper. ISBN 0 8223 3582 4 cloth; 0 8223 3570 0 paper. Land tenure reform has been a point of violent conflict in Zimbabwe for several years as white farmers are forced off their farms. Anthropologist Donald Moore grounds the struggle for control over land deep within the colonial and post-1965 Unilateral Declaration of Independence (UDI) era. Moore's text is based on his fieldwork in 1991Á2 in the Kaerezi area along the Mozambique border. Therefore, the book does not address the most recent evictions. However, power and place have been central issues in the region since the colonial era, when external actors located the international border within the territory of Chief Tangwena. Initially the chief's residence was in Mozambique, but he relocated his residence and loyalty to territory within Zimbabwe. The link to Mozambique remains a key issue in two instances. First, residents are identified as long-term residents or recent arrivals depending on whether or not they relocated from Mozambique. Second, Robert Mugabe fled through the Kaerezi region on his way to Mozambique when escaping Ian Smith's forces. These events are indications of Kaerezi's location on the periphery of the national power structure. Portugal was not able to effectively govern the Mozambican section of the territory, nor was Smith able to secure the Zimbabwean area. The post-UDI period saw an intense struggle for land and labour. Moore traces how those who suffered for this land have earnt respect from the residents. While Mugabe's work in the field of Tangwena territory may be literal or figurative, he certainly suffered for the territory and earnt the support of locals. Meanwhile, white farmers were extracting labour from residents on private land. As white farmers attempted to enforce more stringent labour contracts, residents resisted. Moore does a fine job of portraying the struggle between white and black, core and periphery, sufferers and non-sufferers, chief and rainmaker. He emphasizes how these struggles have been fought over land since land is necessary for life in this underdeveloped periphery. There are times when Moore seems to overemphasize this theme, as he repeats claims of locals 'mapping themselves to the land'. 165 Reviews in brief
